thread.title: Behind Luke Martin, Bayside clicking at the right time
thread.title_full: Behind Luke Martin, Bayside clicking at the right time | HamptonRoads.com | PilotOnline.com

author: Ray Nimmo
title: Behind Luke Martin, Bayside clicking at the right time
text:
VIRGINIA BEACH Only once can Bayside boys volleyball coach Daniel Keros remember senior Luke Martin shouting excitedly.
Last month during a match against Ocean Lakes, Martin - well known for his low-key, nonchalant personality - roared.
"We all had a laugh after," said Martin, an outside hitter.
Bayside (12-5) - ranked No. 1 in South Hampton Roads - is having its best season. A log cabin in the midst of the Cox, Princess Anne and Ocean Lakes skyscrapers through the years, the Marlins have 12 seniors with vast experience.
"They have phenomenal team chemistry," Ocean Lakes coach Heath Boomer said.
Martin leads the crew with a jack-of-all-trades style. He can blast an attack but still tip it at the perfect time.
"He's one of those technicians," Keros said.
His prowess comes with only four years of volleyball experience. He picked it up as a freshman at a neighbor's recommendation. Martin has played soccer and basketball for Bayside but found a niche in volleyball. He replaced basketball with a club volleyball season.
An added bonus to trying out at Bayside: "There were no cuts, so I wouldn't be embarrassed," Martin deadpanned.
Bayside players built a foundation last year as a tough out and recognized they'd be a decent team this year with so many returners. But not this good.
Bayside beat then-No. 1 Ocean Lakes last week to claim sole possession of first place in the Coastal Conference.
The difference this year, Martin and Keros agreed, is having a solid player at every position and a deep bench.
"To be honest this is the first time in my 12 years that I have a complete team," Keros said.
Despite their meteoric rise, the Marlins haven't been caught flat-footed in big games. Their close friendship and trust has held firm. If any nerves creep in, teammates look to Martin.
"I'm real relaxed and chilled in everything I do," Martin said. "When the team is worried, I'm never worried. If we're down 20, I'm still gonna play the same like we're up 30."
That's why Keros looked at his assistant coaches with wide eyes when Martin yelled last month. And also why Keros was shocked to find out Martin sustained an injury that day.
"After playing all day, tons of matches, he comes off the court excited," Keros said. "I tell him to ice up and rest up. Later his dad called me and told me (Martin) kind of threw his arm out. He played through that."
Bayside hopes Martin has a few more tricks up his sleeve come postseason.

FIELD HOCKEY
Rebecca Fraser, a Great Bridge senior, had five goals in a victory over Churchland.
Juel Hayes, a Maury senior, had five goals in a win over Green Run.
Kristyna Oyola, a Salem senior, had the lone goal in a decision over Kempsville.
BOYS VOLLEYBALL
Na'Jon Nobles, a Green Run junior, had 34 assists in a 3-2 win over Salem.
GIRLS VOLLEYBALL
Lindsay Knierbein, a Nansemond-Suffolk junior, tallied 18 digs and five blocks in a win over Norfolk Christian.
Bailey Jones, a Norfolk Collegiate senior, had 27 kills in a 3-2 win over Walsingham.
BOYS SOCCER
Jaylen Hollins, a Portsmouth Christian sophomore, scored the only goal in a victory over previously-unbeaten Atlantic Shores.

WEDNESDAY
Cross country: Atlantic and Coastal conference Both conferences will run at Kellam with spots up for grabs in the South Region championships. The Coastal girls are up first at 3:30 p.m.
